trans-unit.source: How to use Table storage from Ruby | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Table storage from Ruby | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the table storage service in Azure. Code samples are written using the Ruby API.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the table storage service in Azure. Code samples are written using the Ruby API.

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Microsoft Azure Table service.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Microsoft Azure Table service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written written using the Ruby API.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written written using the Ruby API.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating and deleting a table, inserting and querying entities in a table.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating and deleting a table, inserting and querying entities in a table.

trans-unit.source: Create a Ruby application.
trans-unit.target: Create a Ruby application.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <linkText>Create a Ruby Application on Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <linkText>Create a Ruby Application on Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To use Azure storage, you need to download and use the Ruby azure package, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure storage, you need to download and use the Ruby azure package, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.

trans-unit.source: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows), Terminal (Mac), or Bash (Unix).
trans-unit.target: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows), Terminal (Mac), or Bash (Unix).

trans-unit.source: Type gem install azure in the command window to install the gem and dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Type gem install azure in the command window to install the gem and dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Use your favorite text editor, add the following to the top of the Ruby file where you intend to use storage:
trans-unit.target: Use your favorite text editor, add the following to the top of the Ruby file where you intend to use storage:

trans-unit.source: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\_STORAGE\_ACCOUNT and AZURE\_STORAGE\_ACCESS\_KEY for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\_STORAGE\_ACCOUNT and AZURE\_STORAGE\_ACCESS\_KEY for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information before using Azure::TableService with the following code:
trans-unit.target: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information before using Azure::TableService with the following code:

trans-unit.source: To obtain these values:
trans-unit.target: To obtain these values:

trans-unit.source: Log into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log into the <linkText>Azure Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the storage account you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the storage account you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Click MANAGE KEYS at the bottom of the navigation pane.
trans-unit.target: Click MANAGE KEYS at the bottom of the navigation pane.

trans-unit.source: In the pop up dialog, you will see the storage account name, primary access key and secondary access key.
trans-unit.target: In the pop up dialog, you will see the storage account name, primary access key and secondary access key.

trans-unit.source: For access key, you can either the primary one or the secondary one.
trans-unit.target: For access key, you can either the primary one or the secondary one.

trans-unit.source: The Azure::TableService object lets you work with tabls and entities.
trans-unit.target: The Azure::TableService object lets you work with tabls and entities.

trans-unit.source: To create a table, use the create\_table() method.
trans-unit.target: To create a table, use the create\_table() method.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a table or print out the error if there is any.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a table or print out the error if there is any.

trans-unit.source: To add an entity, first create a hash object that defines your entity properties.
trans-unit.target: To add an entity, first create a hash object that defines your entity properties.

trans-unit.source: Note that for every entity you mustspecify a PartitionKey and RowKey.
trans-unit.target: Note that for every entity you mustspecify a PartitionKey and RowKey.

trans-unit.source: These are the unique identifiers of your entities, and are values that can be queried much faster than your other properties.
trans-unit.target: These are the unique identifiers of your entities, and are values that can be queried much faster than your other properties.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Service uses PartitionKey to automatically distribute the table's entities over many storage nodes.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Service uses PartitionKey to automatically distribute the table's entities over many storage nodes.

trans-unit.source: Entities with the same PartitionKey are stored on the same node.
trans-unit.target: Entities with the same PartitionKey are stored on the same node.

trans-unit.source: The RowKey is the unique ID of the entity within the partition it belongs to.
trans-unit.target: The RowKey is the unique ID of the entity within the partition it belongs to.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple methods available to update an existing entity:
trans-unit.target: There are multiple methods available to update an existing entity:

trans-unit.source: update\_entity(): Update an existing entity by replacing it.
trans-unit.target: update\_entity(): Update an existing entity by replacing it.

trans-unit.source: merge\_entity(): Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing entity.
trans-unit.target: merge\_entity(): Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing entity.

trans-unit.source: insert\_or\_merge\_entity(): Updates an existing entity by replacing it.
trans-unit.target: insert\_or\_merge\_entity(): Updates an existing entity by replacing it.

trans-unit.source: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted:
trans-unit.target: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted:

trans-unit.source: insert\_or\_replace\_entity(): Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing entity.
trans-unit.target: insert\_or\_replace\_entity(): Updates an existing entity by merging new property values into the existing entity.

trans-unit.source: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted.
trans-unit.target: If no entity exists, a new one will be inserted.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates updating an entity using update\_entity():
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates updating an entity using update\_entity():

trans-unit.source: With update\_entity() and merge\_entity(), if the entity that is being updated doesn't exist then the update operation will fail.
trans-unit.target: With update\_entity() and merge\_entity(), if the entity that is being updated doesn't exist then the update operation will fail.

trans-unit.source: Therefore if you wish to store an entity regardless of whether it already exists, you should instead use insert\_or\_replace\_entity() or insert\_or\_merge\_entity().
trans-unit.target: Therefore if you wish to store an entity regardless of whether it already exists, you should instead use insert\_or\_replace\_entity() or insert\_or\_merge\_entity().

trans-unit.source: Sometimes it makes sense to submit multiple operations together in a batch to ensure atomic processing by the server.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes it makes sense to submit multiple operations together in a batch to ensure atomic processing by the server.

trans-unit.source: To accomplish that, you first create a Batch object and then use the execute\_batch() method on TableService.
trans-unit.target: To accomplish that, you first create a Batch object and then use the execute\_batch() method on TableService.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates submitting two entities with RowKey 2 and 3 in a batch.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates submitting two entities with RowKey 2 and 3 in a batch.

trans-unit.source: Notice that it only works for entities with the same PartitionKey.
trans-unit.target: Notice that it only works for entities with the same PartitionKey.

trans-unit.source: To query an entity in a table, use the get\_entity() method, by passing the table name, PartitionKey and RowKey.
trans-unit.target: To query an entity in a table, use the get\_entity() method, by passing the table name, PartitionKey and RowKey.

trans-unit.source: To query a set of entities in a table, create a query hash object and use the query\_entities() method.
trans-unit.target: To query a set of entities in a table, create a query hash object and use the query\_entities() method.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates getting all the entities with the same PartitionKey:
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates getting all the entities with the same PartitionKey:

trans-unit.source: Notice that if the result set is too large for a single query to return, a continuation token will be returned which you can use to retrieve subsequent pages.
trans-unit.target: Notice that if the result set is too large for a single query to return, a continuation token will be returned which you can use to retrieve subsequent pages.

trans-unit.source: A query to a table can retrieve just a few properties from an entity.
trans-unit.target: A query to a table can retrieve just a few properties from an entity.

trans-unit.source: This technique, called "projection", reduces bandwidth and can improve query performance, especially for large entities.
trans-unit.target: This technique, called "projection", reduces bandwidth and can improve query performance, especially for large entities.

trans-unit.source: Use the select clause and pass the names of the properties you would like to bring over to the client.
trans-unit.target: Use the select clause and pass the names of the properties you would like to bring over to the client.

trans-unit.source: To delete an entity, use the delete\_entity() method.
trans-unit.target: To delete an entity, use the delete\_entity() method.

trans-unit.source: You need to pas in the name of the table which contains the entity, the PartitionKey and RowKey of the entity.
trans-unit.target: You need to pas in the name of the table which contains the entity, the PartitionKey and RowKey of the entity.

trans-unit.source: To delete a table, use the delete\_table() method and pass in the name of the table you want to delete.
trans-unit.target: To delete a table, use the delete\_table() method and pass in the name of the table you want to delete.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of table storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of table storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.

trans-unit.target: See the MSDN Reference: <linkText>Azure Storage</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: Visit the <linkText>Azure Storage Team Blog</linkText><title></title>
